verses.text: Samson went down to Timnah, and there he saw a woman among the daughters of the Philistines.
verses.comment: Faithful to the Hebrew; 'went down' reflects journey from hill country to the lowlands.

verses.text: He went up and told his father and his mother, 'I have seen a woman in Timnah of the daughters of the Philistines. Now, get her for me as a wife.'
verses.comment: 'Get her for me as a wife' maintains the command form in the Hebrew.

verses.text: Then his father and his mother said to him, 'Is there no woman among the daughters of your relatives or among all our people, that you must go to take a wife from the uncircumcised Philistines?' But Samson said to his father, 'Get her for me, for she is right in my eyes.'
verses.comment: The phrase 'she is right in my eyes' is a literal rendering of a Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Now his father and mother did not know that this was from the Lord, for he was seeking an opportunity against the Philistines. At that time the Philistines ruled over Israel.
verses.comment: Added punctuation for clarity; 'seeking an opportunity' translates 'seeking an occasion.'

verses.text: So Samson went down to Timnah with his father and mother. As they approached the vineyards of Timnah, suddenly a young lion came roaring toward him.
verses.comment: 'Roaring toward him' is a close translation; Hebrew implies aggressive charging.

verses.text: Then the Spirit of the Lord came mightily upon him, so that he tore the lion apart with his bare hands as he would have torn a young goat. But he did not tell his father or mother what he had done.
verses.comment: 'Came mightily upon him' keeps the original sense of sudden empowerment.

verses.text: Then he went down and talked with the woman, and she was right in Samson's eyes.
verses.comment: Repeats idiom of 'right in his eyes' to match Hebrew phrasing.

verses.text: After some time, he returned to marry her, and as he turned aside to look at the carcass of the lion, he saw a swarm of bees and honey inside the carcass.
verses.comment: Phrase 'after some time' renders 'after days' idiomatically.

verses.text: He took some of it in his hands and went along, eating as he went. And when he reached his father and mother, he gave some to them, and they ate. But he did not tell them that he had taken the honey from the lion's carcass.
verses.comment: Faithful to the Hebrew sequence and omission.

verses.text: His father went down to the woman, and Samson prepared a feast there, for this was customary among young men.
verses.comment: 'Prepared a feast' makes explicit the traditional wedding banquet.

verses.text: When the people saw him, they brought thirty companions to be with him.
verses.comment: 'Thirty companions' refers to groomsmen or attendants provided by the bride's side.

verses.text: Samson said to them, 'Let me now put a riddle to you. If you can explain it to me within the seven days of the feast and solve it, then I will give you thirty linen garments and thirty changes of clothes.'
verses.comment: 'Changes of clothes' is literal; linen garments were expensive garments.

verses.text: But if you cannot explain it to me, then you must give me thirty linen garments and thirty changes of clothes.' They said to him, 'Pose your riddle, so we may hear it.'
verses.comment: Direct dialogue maintained for clarity.

verses.text: So he said to them, 'Out of the eater came something to eat, and out of the strong came something sweet.' But for three days they could not solve the riddle.
verses.comment: Riddle is translated as literally as possible.

verses.text: On the fourth day they said to Samson's wife, 'Entice your husband to explain the riddle to us, or we will burn you and your father's house with fire. Did you invite us here to impoverish us?'
verses.comment: Threat is explicit; phrase 'impoverish us' is a literal rendering.

verses.text: So Samson's wife wept before him and said, 'You only hate me; you do not love me. You have put a riddle to my countrymen, but you have not explained it to me.' He answered her, 'See, I have not explained it to my father or my mother, so should I explain it to you?'
verses.comment: Dialogue preserved closely to the Hebrew.

verses.text: She wept before him the seven days that their feast lasted. On the seventh day he told her, because she pressed him hard. Then she explained the riddle to her people.
verses.comment: 'Pressed him hard' is a literal translation.

verses.text: On the seventh day, before the sun went down, the men of the city said to him, 'What is sweeter than honey? What is stronger than a lion?' And he replied, 'If you had not plowed with my heifer, you would not have solved my riddle.'
verses.comment: 'Plowed with my heifer' is a literal rendering of an ancient idiom meaning 'used my wife.'

verses.text: Then the Spirit of the Lord came mightily upon him, and he went down to Ashkelon and struck down thirty of their men. He took their belongings and gave the clothes to those who had explained the riddle. In burning anger he went up to his father’s house.
verses.comment: 'Struck down' is a direct translation of 'killed.'

verses.text: But Samson’s wife was given to his companion, who had been his friend at the wedding.
verses.comment: 'Companion' may mean best man or appointed groomsman.
